content.text: (i) Using the information on Fig. 1.1, state and explain which racing car, X or Y , has the greater acceleration between time \(=2 \mathrm{~s}\) and time \(=4 \mathrm{~s}\)
racing car
explanation
(ii) Determine the speed of racing car Y at time \(=10 \mathrm{~s}\)
speed = m/s
(iii) Determine the distance moved by racing car X from time \(=0\) to time \(=4.0 \mathrm{~s}\)
distance = m
1 (a) Fig. 1.1 shows the speed–time graphs for two racing cars, X and Y , at the beginning of a race
(i) Force \(B\) is described as 'the driving force'
Describe:
force \(C\)
force \(D\)
(ii) The racing car is decelerating along a straight horizontal track
The value of force \(D\) is 2800 N
Suggest a value for force \(B\)
force \(B=\) N
[Total: 8]
(b) Fig. 1.2 shows the directions of four forces, \(A, B, C\) and \(D\), acting on a racing car
(a) Calculate the mass of the heavy hammer
mass = \(\mathrm{kg}\)
(b) The machine lifts the heavy hammer through 0.72 m vertically
Calculate the work done by the machine in lifting the heavy hammer. Include the unit
work done = \(\mathrm{unit}\)
(c) The heavy hammer falls onto the metal rod and pushes it into the ground
Describe the energy transfers from the heavy hammer to the metal rod
Your answer should refer to energy stores as well as transfers between energy stores
2 Some buildings are built on large, strong metal rods that are pushed deep into the ground
A machine drops a heavy hammer onto each metal rod to push it into the ground, as shown in Fig. 2.1
The weight of the heavy hammer is 25000 N
3 (a) A student determines the weight \(W\) of a metal block by using a 1.5 N load and a uniform metre ruler. She places the centre of the uniform metre ruler on a pivot
She moves the metal block and the 1.5 N load until the uniform metre ruler balances horizontally as shown in Fig. 3.1
Calculate the weight \(W\) of the metal block. Use the principle of moments in your answer
weight \(W =\) N
(b) A different metal block is lying on the ground, as shown in Fig. 3.2
The weight of the metal block is 890 N
Calculate the pressure on the ground caused by the block in the position shown in Fig. 3.2
pressure = N/m²
[Total: 7]
(i) The movement of the particles in a gas is
(ii) The forces between the particles in a gas are
(iii) The gas exerts a pressure because the moving gas particles
(iv) As the temperature of a fixed volume of gas decreases, the pressure exerted by the gas
4 (a) Complete the sentences about the kinetic particle model of matter
(b) (i) State the value, in degrees Celsius, of the lowest possible temperature
lowest possible temperature = \(^{\circ}C\)
(ii) State the term used for the lowest possible temperature
5 (a) A teacher produces a water wave in a ripple tank
The wavelength of the water wave is 1.2 cm
The speed of the water wave is 18 cm/s
Calculate the frequency of the water wave
frequency = \(\mathrm{Hz}\)
(i) State the name of the process shown in Fig. 5.1 that occurs at the boundaries between air and glass
(ii) A ray of white light replaces the ray of red light, as shown in Fig. 5.2. The ray of white light splits into different colours
Draw on Fig. 5.2 to show the dispersion of white light to produce a coloured spectrum on a screen. Label the red and violet (purple) parts of the spectrum
(b) Fig. 5.1 shows a ray of red light passing through a prism and emerging into the air
(i) The reading on thermometer Y is not \(24^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)
Explain why the readings on the two thermometers are not the same
(ii) Suggest a value for the reading on thermometer Y
thermometer Y reading = \(^\circ \mathrm{C}\)
6 (a) A teacher uses the equipment shown in Fig. 6.1
The thermometers X and Y are the same distance from the bottle
The room temperature is \(20^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)
The teacher pours very hot water into the bottle
After 5 minutes, the teacher observes the reading on each thermometer
The reading on thermometer X is \(24^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)

(b) A student demonstrates convection in a liquid. The student has a water supply and the following equipment: a candle, a glass beaker, a tripod and some coloured crystals. The coloured crystals dissolve in warm water
Describe how the student can demonstrate convection in a liquid by using the equipment shown in Fig. 6.2. You may draw a diagram as part of your answer
7 (a) Place ticks \((\checkmark)\) in Table 7.1 to show the properties of sound waves and of microwaves
(b) Scientists have placed reflectors on the Moon. Scientists use the reflectors to measure the distance between the Earth and the Moon
A scientist in an observatory sends a ray of red light from the observatory to the reflector on the Moon, as shown in Fig. 7.1
The ray takes a total time of 2.5 s to travel from the observatory to the reflector and back to the observatory. The speed of light is \(3.0 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\)
Calculate the distance between the observatory and the reflector
distance = m
(c) (i) State one use of ultraviolet rays
(ii) State one harmful effect of ultraviolet rays
(a) Suggest why a pull cord is safer than a push switch for a fan heater in a bathroom
(b) Fig. 8.2 shows the electric circuit for the fan heater
State the name for component X and for component Y
(c) Fig. 8.3 shows the information label on the fan heater
Calculate the current supplied to the fan heater
current = A
8 Fig. 8.1 shows a mains-powered electric fan heater fixed on a bathroom wall
The pull cord switches the fan heater on and off
(a) Calculate the combined resistance of the two resistors in series
combined resistance = \(\Omega\)
(i) Calculate the potential difference (p.d.) across the \(20 \Omega\) resistor
potential difference = V
(ii) A student uses a voltmeter to measure the potential difference across the \(20 \Omega\) resistor
Draw on Fig. 9.2 to show how the student connects the voltmeter. Use the correct circuit symbol for the voltmeter
(b) The two resistors in Fig. 9.1 are connected to an ammeter and a 12 V battery, as shown in Fig. 9.2
The reading on the ammeter is 0.20 A
(c) The student removes the two resistors and then connects them in parallel, as shown in Fig. 9.3
Suggest a value for the combined resistance of the two resistors in parallel
combined resistance = \(\Omega\)
9 Fig. 9.1 shows two resistors connected in series
(i) State the number of protons in one nucleus of radon-222
number of protons = \(\mathrm{number of protons = }\)
(ii) Determine the number of neutrons in one nucleus of radon-222
number of neutrons = \(\mathrm{number of neutrons = }\)
10 (a) Radon-222 is a radioactive gas that emits alpha \((\alpha)\) particles
The nuclide notation for radon-222 is \(\frac{222}{86} \mathrm{Rn}\)
(b) A sample containing 60 mg of radon-222 decays to 7.5 mg in 11.5 days
Calculate the half-life of radon-222
half-life = \(\mathrm{half-life = }\) days
[Total: 7]
(c) Radon gas is one source of background radiation
Name two other sources that make a significant contribution to background radiation
(a) Complete the three missing labels on Fig. 11.1 by writing the name of each planet on its dotted line
(b) (i) The Sun consists mainly of two elements
Name the two elements
(ii) The Sun radiates energy mainly in three regions of the electromagnetic spectrum. Ultraviolet is one of the three regions
State the name of one of the other two regions
Scientists use the Big Bang Theory to explain the way the Universe began
State one piece of evidence that supports the Big Bang Theory
Scientists use the accretion model to explain the formation of the Solar System
Complete the following sentences about the accretion model
In space, there are clouds of dust and
The material spins around and moves closer together due to the force of
This forms an accretion
11 Fig. 11.1 represents the Solar System. The Sun and five of the eight planets are labelled
